{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{EngvarB|date=May 2017}} The '''999 phone charging myth''' is an [[urban myth]] which claims that if a [[mobile phone]] has low battery then dialing [[999 (emergency telephone number)|999]] (or any regional [[emergency number]]) charges the phone so it has more power. This was confirmed as a myth by several British police forces who publicly cited the dangers of making such calls.
== Basis == The basis for the myth was a feature of [[BlackBerry]] phones: If the battery level was too low, the phone automatically locked down phone features and shut down the phone radio for all calls except to emergency services. People discovered that if they dialed 999 then immediately hung up, it would override the shutdown for a number of minutes so that phone calls could be made.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.socialstudent.co.uk/calling-the-police-doesnt-charge-your-phone-battery/ |title=Calling The Police Doesn't Charge Your Phone Battery |publisher=Social Student |date=18 January 2016 |accessdate=24 May 2017}}</ref>
== Response == The myth is believed to have originated in BlackBerry forums around 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.derbyshiretimes.co.uk/news/crime/derbyshire-ignore-phone-myth-cops-urge-1-5996352/amp |title=Ignore phone myth, cops urge |work=Derbyshire Times |date=30 August 2013 |accessdate=24 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://forums.crackberry.com/blackberry-bold-9930-9900-f235/battery-too-low-radio-use-warning-694982/ |title="Battery too low for radio use" warning |publisher=BlackBerry Forums |date= |accessdate=24 May 2017}}</ref> In 2013, [[Derbyshire Constabulary]] released a press release telling people not to believe the myth that calling 999 charges the battery.<ref name=db /> They cited that for every silent or aborted 999 call received, the operators have to call the person back to make sure there is no emergency.<ref name=db>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.itv.com/news/anglia/2014-01-13/police-warning-over-mobile-phone-urban-myth/ |title=Police warning over mobile phone urban myth |publisher=ITV |date=13 January 2014 |accessdate=24 May 2017}}</ref> These [[hoax calls]] waste police time that could potentially block responses to real emergencies.<ref>{{cite web|author=Paul Cockerton |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/dialling-999-not-charge-mobile-2234973 |title=Dialling 999 does NOT charge mobile battery: Derbyshire Police issue warning over urban myth |work=The Mirror |date=29 August 2013 |accessdate=24 May 2017}}</ref> [[Bedfordshire Police]] also released information asking people not to call 999 except for an emergency as they stated that in the last six months of 2013 they had an increase in hoax 999 calls from people believing the myth.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.itv.com/news/anglia/2014-01-15/police-dispel-999-myth/ |title=Police dispel 999 myth |publisher=ITV |date=15 January 2014 |accessdate=24 May 2017}}</ref> Other sources supplemented these press releases by stating that misusing the 999 number is illegal.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/01/13/999-battery-hoax_n_4588617.html |title=Calling 999 Does NOT Boost Your Mobile Phone Battery, Police Warn As Hoax Persists |work=Huffington Post UK |date=13 January 2014 |accessdate=24 May 2017}}</ref> They also stated that the police could cut off telephones being used to abuse the 999 service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lutontoday.co.uk/news/you-might-be-charged-yourself-if-you-try-to-power-up-your-mobile-1-5873160/amp |title=You might be charged yourself if you try to power up your mobile |work=The Luton News |date=12 February 2014 |accessdate=24 May 2017}}</ref>
A related myth emerged: that when [[Siri]] on an [[iPhone]] is told, "Charge my phone to 100%", the phone would call emergency services as a secret safety code. This was later traced to a bug in [[Apple Inc|Apple]] programming that was fixed within a day. The myth continued to spread on social media as a prank.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/siri-charge-phone-police/ |title=Telling Siri to 'Charge My Phone to 100%' Summons Police |publisher=Snopes.com |date= |accessdate=8 June 2017}}</ref>

The '''AIDSRides''' were a series of fundraising events organised by Pallotta TeamWorks which raised more than $105 million for critical AIDS services and medical research.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} About half of the money raised directly benefited AIDS patients.{{cite news| url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2001-12-13/news/17632518_1_aids-patients-pat-christen-executive-director-aids-and-hiv | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | title=AIDS Ride planners sue S.F. charity over new race | date=2001-12-13}} In 2001, the [[San Francisco AIDS Foundation]] and the [[Los Angeles Gay and Lesbian Center]] ended their partnership with the California AIDSRide over concerns that not enough money was going to the charities. They hired Honeycutt Group, a consulting firm started by three former Pallotta TeamWorks employees, to organize [[AIDS/LifeCycle]], a similar event. [[Dan Pallotta]] unsuccessfully sued the "copycat" event,{{cite news| url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fsb/fsb_archive/2002/03/01/319484/index.htm | work=CNN | title=Dan Pallotta's bike-tour and walkathon business has raised more than $200 million for AIDS research & other charities. So why do some people hate him so much?* *Hint: Check out the Lexus in his driveway | date=2002-03-01}} but the competition and surrounding controversy made 2002 the event's last year. ==Ride list== Pallotta TeamWorks has organised several AIDSRides in North America:{{cite web |url=http://www.pallottateamworks.com/1_about/history_all.htm |title=About Pallotta TeamWorks |accessdate=2008-02-14 |work=Pallotta TeamWorks Website |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071212165355/http://www.pallottateamworks.com/1_about/history_all.htm |archivedate=2007-12-12 |deadurl=yes |df= }} # California: 1994–2002 # Boston>New York, 1994–2002 # Philadelphia to DC: Philadelphia, Pa. to Washington, D.C., 1996
TeamWorks was fined by Pa. Attorney General for improper fund raising. [http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fsb/fsb_archive/2002/03/01/319484/index.htm] #Florida AIDS Ride from Orlando to Miami (South Beach) 1996-97 # Washington, DC AIDS Ride (NC to DC) 1997–2002 # Heartland: Twin Cities to Chicago, 1996–2002 # Northeast: New York to Boston, or reverse, 1995–2002 # Texas: 1998–2002 # Alaska AIDS Vaccine Ride: 2000–2001 # Montana AIDS Vaccine Ride: 2001 # [[AIDS Vaccine Bike Trek|Montreal to Portland, Maine]]: 2001 # European AIDS Vaccine Ride: 2002 ==See also== * [[Positive pedalers]] * [[Los Angeles Gay and Lesbian Center]] * [[San Francisco AIDS Foundation]] * [[Ride for AIDS Chicago]] * [[List of health related charity fundraisers]] * [[AIDS/LifeCycle]] * [[AIDS Vaccine 200]] * [[Empire State AIDS Ride]] * [[Wisconsin AIDS Ride]] * [[New Jersey Ride Against AIDS]] * California AIDS Ride '94 * [[Charity Treks]] * [[Hill Country Ride for AIDS]] * [[BrakingAIDSRide]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.charitytreks.com Charity Treks Montreal to Portland 10th Anniversary ~ 2011] *[http://pallottateamworks.com/ Pallotta TeamWorks] and [http://www.pallottateamworks.com/about_pallotta.php Pallotta TeamWorks history] *[http://www.aidslifecycle.org/index.html AIDS/LifeCycle | 7-Day 545 Mile Cycling Event to Support HIV/AIDS Services] *[http://rideforAIDS.org Ride for AIDS Chicago | The Midwest's only 2-day, 200-mile cycling Event to Support HIV/AIDS Services] *[http://rfac.org Ride For A Cause] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080615132051/http://www.empirestateaidsride.org/ Empire State AIDS Ride] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080517102949/http://actride.org/ Wisconsin AIDS Ride] *[http://www.njrideagainstaids.org/ New Jersey Ride Against AIDS] *[http://www.tofighthiv.org/site/TR/SFAFCyclingEvent/SFAFEnduranceEventsTrainingProgram?fr_id=1050&pg=entry Seismic Challenge] *[http://www.actioncycling.org/ AIDS Vaccine 200] *[http://www.hillcountryride.org/ Hill Country Ride for AIDS] [[Category:Health-related fundraisers]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS organizations]] [[Category:Lists of events]] {{Cycling-stub}} {{philanthropy-org-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} '''Accidental incest''' is [[Human sexual activity|sexual activity]] or [[marriage]] between persons who were unaware of a family relationship between them which would be considered [[incest]]uous.
The laws of many jurisdictions [[Void marriage|void incestuous marriages]], even if entered into without awareness of the kinship. If an incestuous relationship is suspected, [[DNA testing]] may be used. Some jurisdictions permit offspring of IVF donations access to donation records or to adoption records.
==Causes== People may be unaware of a [[kinship]] relationship between them in a number of circumstances. For example, [[artificial insemination]] with an anonymous [[sperm donation|donated sperm]] may result in offspring being unaware of any biological relations, such as paternity or half siblings. To reduce the likelihood of accidental incest, fertility clinics usually limit the number of times that a donor's sperm may be used.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9iJlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RYgNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2368,2279497&dq=accidental-incest |title=Accidental Incest Risk Increases |date=15 March 1979 |work=Edmonton Journal |agency=Associated Press |page=61 |accessdate=23 March 2011 |location=Boston}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=coNSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hwUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6125,3788930&dq=accidental-incest |title=Report From A Test Tube Baby |last=Atallah |first=Lillian |date=19 April 1976 |work=Ocala Star-Banner |page=35 |accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref> Some countries have laws limiting the number of children a donor can father.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/30/international/europe/30sperm.html |title=Spreading Scandinavian Genes, Without Viking Boats |last=Alvarez |first=Lizette |date=30 September 2004 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref> while others limit sperm donations based on family numbers to enable one family to have true siblings.
[[Taiwan]] allows those conceived by artificial means to find out if they are related to a person they are considering marrying.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2007/05/11/2003360370 |title=DOH working on provision to stop accidental incest |last=Oung |first=Angelica |date=11 May 2007 |work=The Taipei Times |page=2 |accessdate=23 March 2011 |location=Taiwan}}</ref>
Accidental incest may also arise in the following situations: * Children separated from their family at birth, * [[Child abandonment]],<ref>{{cite book |last=Angelica |first=Jade Christine |title=A Moral Emergency: Breaking the Cycle of Child Sexual Abuse |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-F92TlEyr8oC&pg=PA59&dq=%22accidental+incest%22&ei=-P-HTa2tOKqO0QHR58T9DQ&resnum=2&ved=0CC0Q6AEwATgK&q=%22accidental%20incest%22 |page=59}}</ref> * Sexual exploration.
==Notable cases== *In 2008, it was reported that a British brother and sister, who were twins separated at birth, married without knowing of their relationship. According to the report, the relationship was discovered soon after their wedding, and the marriage was annulled. The case has raised the issue regarding whether adoptions should be kept secret.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/01/11/twins.married/?imw=Y&iref=mpstoryemail |title=Unknowing twins married, lawmaker says |publisher=CNN |accessdate=23 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://culturekitchen.com/mole333/blog/accidental_incest_twins_separated_at_birth_marr |title=Accidental Incest: Twins Separated at Birth Marry |last=Sabater |first=Liza |publisher=Culture Kitchen |accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref> Concerns have been raised, however, about whether the story is, in fact, true.<ref>{{cite news |first=Jon |last=Henley |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2008/jan/15/familyandrelationships.jonhenley |title=Did a pair of twins really get married by mistake? |work=The Guardian |accessdate=3 April 2012 |location=London |date=15 January 2008}}</ref> *An engaged couple in South Africa, who had been together for five years and were expecting a child, discovered that they were brother and sister just before their wedding. They were raised separately and met as adults in college. Just before the wedding, their parents met and they came to realize that they were siblings. The couple broke off the relationship after the discovery.<ref>{{cite news |first=Stewart |last=Maclean |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2057081/Engaged-couple-discover-brother-sister-parents-meet-days-wedding.html |title=Engaged couple discover they are brother and sister when their parents meet just before wedding |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |date=3 November 2011 |accessdate=9 November 2011}}</ref>

'''Anthrax hoaxes''' involving the use of white powder or labels to falsely suggest the use of [[anthrax]] are frequently reported in the United States and globally. [[Hoax]]es have increased following the [[2001 anthrax attacks]], after which no genuine anthrax attacks have occurred. The [[FBI]] and [[United States Postal Inspection Service|U.S. postal inspectors]] have responded to thousands of "white powder events" and targets have included government offices, US embassies, banks and news organizations.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/mar/08/nation/na-anthrax-threats8|title=Anthrax hoaxes pile up, as does their cost|last=Drogin|first=Bob|date=8 March 2009|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Cole|first=Leonard A.|title=The Anthrax Letters: A Bioterrorism Expert Investigates the Attacks That Shocked America--Case Closed?|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing|year=2009|isbn=978-1-60239-715-6|url=http://leonardcole.com}}</ref>
==History== Anthrax hoaxes were sporadically reported in the 1990s,<ref>{{cite book|last=Carus|first=W. Seth|author2=Center for Counterproliferation Research |author3=National Defense University |title=Bioterrorism and biocrimes: the illicit use of biological agents since 1900|publisher=The Minerva Group, Inc.|year=2002|volume=8|chapter=Thrreatened Use (Anthrax Hoaxes)|isbn=1-4101-0023-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1jEP8Ve4zwgC}}</ref> including a petri dish in an envelope labeled "anthrachs"[sic] sent to [[B'nai B'rith]] in Washington in 1997 that contained harmless ''[[Bacillus cereus]]'',<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/25/us/suspicious-package-prompts-8-hour-vigil-at-b-nai-b-rith.html|title=Suspicious Package Prompts 8-Hour Vigil at B'nai B'rith|date=24 April 1997|work=New York Times|accessdate=10 December 2009 | first=Matthew L. | last=Wald}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://reason.com/archives/2001/10/10/anthrax-attack|title=Anthrax Attack?|last=Bailey|first=Ronald|date=10 October 2001|work=Reason|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/07/12/opinion/the-anthrax-files.html|title=The Anthrax Files|last=Kristof|first=Nicholas D.|date=12 July 2002|work=New York Times|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref> but a spate of anthrax threats followed the 1998 arrest of Larry Wayne Harris, a microbiologist and [[white supremacist]]. Harris released what he said was military-grade anthrax but was actually a harmless vaccine strain, but news coverage popularized the idea of anthrax among hoaxers.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Tucker|first=Jonathan B.|date=July 1999|title=Historical trends related to bioterrorism: An empirical analysis|journal=Emerging Infectious Diseases|publisher=CDC|volume=5|issue=4|url=http://origin.cdc.gov/ncidod/EID/vol5no4/tucker.htm | pmid = 10458952|doi=10.3201/eid0504.990406|pmc=2627752|pages=498–504}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adl.org/learn/anthrax/Harris.asp?xpicked=3&item=5|title=The Harris Hoax|work=ADL|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref> In response to these hoaxes, the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] released guidance for public health authorities for handling bioterrorism threats.<ref>{{cite journal|year=1999|author1=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)|title=Bioterrorism Alleging Use of Anthrax and Interim Guidelines for Management -- United States, 1998|journal=MMWR|publisher=CDC|volume=48|issue=4|pages=69–74|url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00056353.htm|pmid=10023627}}</ref>
===Post-2001=== [[File:Anthrax hoax in Rhode Island in 2004.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Suspect letter with white powder that was dealt with by Rhode Island Department of Environmental Management emergency responders. It was a hoax.]] In the month following the 2001 anthrax attacks, hundreds of hoaxes were reported worldwide.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1071/NB03059|last=Leask|first=Alexander|author2=Valerie Delpech |author3=Jeremy McAnulty|title=Anthrax and other suspect powders: Initial responses to an outbreak of hoaxes and scares|journal=New South Wales Public Health Bulletin|publisher=Csiro Publishing|volume=14|issue=12|pages=218–221|url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/nid/226/paper/NB03059.htm|year=2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2001/oct/21/anthrax.terrorism|title=Anthrax hoax chaos|last=Harris|first=Paul|date=21 October 2001|work=The Observer|accessdate=10 December 2009 | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/sept11/2001/11/06/hoaxes-usat.htm|title=Anthrax hoaxes persist despite arrests|last=Kasindorf|first=Martin|author2=Toni Locy|date=6 November 2001|work=USA Today|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref> Legislation was enacted in the UK in October 2001 so that anyone convicted of a hoax involving threats of biological, chemical, nuclear or radioactive contamination would face a seven-year prison sentence.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1360077/Spore-hoaxers-face-jail-terms-from-today.html|title=Spore hoaxers face jail terms from today|last=Murphy|first=Joe|date=21 October 2001|work=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=10 December 2009 | location=London}}</ref> The Anti-Hoax Terrorism Act 2001 was passed by the US House of Representatives<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2001/11/14/loc_dewine_proposes.html|title=DeWine proposes tough law on anthrax hoaxes|last=DePledge|first=Derrick|date=14 November 2001|work=Cincinnati Enquirer|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref> but never enacted,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h107-3209|title=H.R. 3209: Anti-Hoax Terrorism Act of 2001|work=Govtrack|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref> and legislation making terrorism hoaxes a federal offence was finally passed as part of the [[Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act]] of 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cid.army.mil/documents/Lookout/Military%20Hoaxes_web.pdf |title=Violators of Military Hoaxes Act could receive fines, prison time |work=CID Lookout |publisher=U.S. Army Criminal Investigation Command |accessdate=10 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717135437/http://www.cid.army.mil/documents/Lookout/Military%20Hoaxes_web.pdf |archivedate=17 July 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/ac2/wp-dyn/A53452-2004Dec9?language=printer|title=Measure Expands Police Powers|last=Eggen|first=Dan|date=10 December 2004|work=Washington Post|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s108-2845|title=S. 2845: Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004|work=Govtrack|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref>
==Cases== One of the most prolific hoaxers was [[Clayton Waagner]], an [[anti-abortion]] activist who mailed hundreds of anthrax hoax letters to abortion clinics in late 2001<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/1695140.stm|title=US anthrax hoax suspect arrested|date=6 December 2001|work=BBC News|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref> and who was convicted in December 2003.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2003-12-03-anthrax-hoax_x.htm|title=Man is convicted in anthrax hoax case|work=Associated Press|accessdate=10 December 2009 | date=3 December 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://dir.salon.com/story/news/feature/2003/12/10/waagner/index.html |title=The quiet fall of an American terrorist |last=Clarkson |first=Frederick |date=10 December 2003 |work=Salon |accessdate=10 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110320083801/http://dir.salon.com/story/news/feature/2003/12/10/waagner/index.html |archivedate=20 March 2011 |df= }}</ref> A Sacramento man, Marc M. Keyser, admitted to sending around 120 packages marked as containing anthrax in October 2008, which he says was to highlight the lack of preparedness of the [[U.S. Department of Homeland Security]] and public for an anthrax attack. He was convicted in September 2009 of five counts of hoaxes and making threats<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sacbee.com/ourregion/story/2191521.html|title=Sacramentan convicted for sending anthrax hoax messages|last=Walsh|first=Denny|date=18 September 2009|work=Sacramento Bee|accessdate=10 December 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/wires/ap/us/2009/09/17/D9APEMG81_us_anthrax_scare/ |title=Calif. man convicted in nationwide anthrax scare |date=17 September 2009 |work=Salon |accessdate=10 December 2009 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and sentenced to four years in prison in late April 2010.<ref>[http://gsn.nti.org/gsn/nw_20100427_9709.php gsn.nti.org]</ref>
In November 2008, white powder was mailed to temples of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (Mormons) in [[Los Angeles California Temple|Los Angeles]] and [[Salt Lake Temple|Salt Lake City]], causing both to be closed temporarily while the mailings were investigated. There was speculation the mailings were in protest of the support by the Church for [[Proposition 8]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/27707413/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/t/white-powder-sent-mormon-temples/|title=White powder sent to Mormon temples|work=Associated Press|date=13 November 2008|accessdate=14 October 2011}}</ref>
Notable recipients of anthrax hoax letters include journalist [[Judith Miller (journalist)|Judith Miller]], author of ''[[Germs: Biological Weapons and America's Secret War]]'', who received one at the ''New York Times'' offices in October 2001.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/10/15/opinion/in-america-living-with-fear.html|title=In America; Living With Fear|last=Herbert|first=Bob|date=15 October 2001|work=New York Times|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{infobox concert tour | concert_tour_name = Asia Tour (Cancelled) | image = Celine Dion Japan Tour 2014 Poster.png | image_size = 220px | border = yes | album = ''[[Loved Me Back to Life]]'' | artist = [[Celine Dion]] | last_tour = [[Sans attendre Tour]]
(2013) | this_tour = '''Asia Tour'''
(2014) | next_tour = [[Summer Tour 2016]]
(2016) }} The '''Asia Tour''' was planned to be the eleventh concert tour by Canadian singer Celine Dion. The tour was organized to support the English language album ''[[Loved Me Back to Life]]'', and was scheduled to take place in October and November 2014.{{Cite web |url=http://www.celinedion.com/ca/press/celines-concert-dates-japan-announced |title=Archived copy |access-date=29 June 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714142420/http://www.celinedion.com/ca/press/celines-concert-dates-japan-announced |archive-date=14 July 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} It would have marked Dion's first concerts in Asia since the [[Taking Chances World Tour]] in 2008. While Japan and the Philippines were the only confirmed stops of the tour, it has been revealed that the singer was planned to be performing dates in several Asian countries for the very first time. ==Background== The tour was organized to support the English language album ''[[Loved Me Back to Life]]'', and was scheduled to take place in October and November 2014. Japan and the Philippines were officially announced. However, there were unofficial dates and venues for Taiwan, China, South Korea, Malaysia and Thailand but because of the cancellation the ticket were never put on sale. In total, 14 concerts were supposed to take place. ==Commercial performance== Celine's concerts in Tokyo and Osaka sold out immediately after tickets went on sale.http://www.hipjpn.co.jp/live/celine/ticket.html ==Cancellation== On 13 August 2014, Dion has announced that the tour has been cancelled due to ongoing illness and family issues. According to a statement released by the singer: {{cquote|"I want to devote every ounce of my strength and energy to my [[René Angélil|husband]]'s healing, and to do so, it's important for me to dedicate this time to him and to our children," Dion said in a statement. "I also want to apologize to all my fans everywhere, for inconveniencing them, and I thank them so much for their love and support."{{cite web|url=http://www.celinedion.com/ca/news/celine-puts-show-business-career-hold-her-health-and-family-reasons|title=Celine Dion announces show biz hiatus to focus on ailing husband|work=Celine: Las Vegas Official Website|publisher=[[AEG Live]]|accessdate=13 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813231818/http://www.celinedion.com/ca/news/celine-puts-show-business-career-hold-her-health-and-family-reasons|archive-date=13 August 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}}} Dion did not return to Asia for a performance until her [[Celine Dion Live 2018|2018 tour]].https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/international/8455647/celine-dion-2018-asia-tour-dates ==Opening acts== In the official announcement for the Japan and Philippine tour, it was revealed that the impersonator [[Véronic DiCaire]] had been invited to join Celine as the opening act for these shows. ==Set list== The official setlist had yet to be announced, although in an exclusive video message to her Japanese fans, Dion promised a new show featuring songs from her latest English album, ''[[Loved Me Back to Life]]'', as well as fan favorites from the past.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dem_HyX9WcY Celine was also rehearsing one song in Japanese and one in Mandarin for the tour. ==Announced Tour dates== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! style="width:150px;"|Date ! style="width:150px;"|City ! style="width:150px;"|Country ! style="width:250px;"|Venue |- ! colspan="6" style="text-align:center;"| Asia (Cancelled){{cite web|author=|url=http://www.celinedion.com/ca/news/celine%E2%80%99s-concert-manila-announced|title=Celine's Concert in Manila Announced!|publisher=CelineDion.com|date=|accessdate=22 July 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140723214836/http://www.celinedion.com/ca/news/celine%E2%80%99s-concert-manila-announced|archive-date=23 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.celinedion.com/ca/press/celines-concert-dates-japan-announced|title=Celine's Concert Dates in Japan Announced!|publisher=CelineDion.com|date=|accessdate=29 June 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714142420/http://www.celinedion.com/ca/press/celines-concert-dates-japan-announced|archive-date=14 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.celinedion.com/ca/news/celine-puts-show-business-career-hold-her-health-and-family-reasons|title=Celine Puts Show Business Career On Hold For Her Health And Family Reasons|accessdate=13 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813231818/http://www.celinedion.com/ca/news/celine-puts-show-business-career-hold-her-health-and-family-reasons|archive-date=13 August 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} |- |11 November 2014 |[[Nagoya]] |rowspan="4"|[[Japan]] |[[Nagoya Dome]] |- |14 November 2014 |[[Osaka]] |[[Osaka Dome]] |- |18 November 2014 |rowspan="2"|[[Tokyo]] |rowspan="2"|[[Tokyo Dome]] |- |19 November 2014 |- |- |26 November 2014{{ref|SON|[A]|[A]}} |[[Manila]] |rowspan="2"|[[Philippines]] |[[Solaire Resort & Casino]] |- |29 November 2014 |[[Pasay City]] |[[Mall of Asia Arena]] |} ==Rumoured Tour dates== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2012}} '''Brian Worley''' (born September 8, 1972) is an American reality television host, [[event planner]], and wedding designer. Worley is the co-owner of Your BASH! Event Production where he has produced numerous events within the entertainment industry.<ref name="huffingtonpost">[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/brian-worley "Brian Worley"], ''[[Huffington Post]]''. Retrieved August 2, 2012.</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Making Dreams Come True|url=http://www.weddingjournalonline.com/|publisher= Wedding Journal Online}}</ref>
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Brian Worley Event Planner.jpg|thumb|right|Brian Worley]] -->
==Early life== Worley was born in [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana]] before he moved to [[Denver, Colorado]] at age 2 and [[Austin, Texas]] at age 12, where he and his younger sister were raised.
While in high school, Worley worked as camp counselor for Lost Creek Country Club.<ref>[http://www.clubcorp.com/Clubs/Lost-Creek-Country-Club "Lost Creek Country Club"]</ref> By spring of 1992, Worley had gained work experience from 3 different jobs including a sales associate position with [[Gap (clothing retailer)|The Gap]], a tour guide position with Disney World’s Great Movie Ride, where he also played the role of [[Sleeping Beauty|Sleeping Beauty's]] Prince Phillip and Disney’s character Goofy.
Worley graduated cum laude from the [[University of North Texas]] with a degree in Radio, Television, and Film.<ref name="huffingtonpost" />
==Career==
Worley launched his first business in fashion with B Worley Designs, a clothing design company that expanded its business to stores throughout Texas. Although thriving as a new clothing company at the time, he pursued his true passion in wedding and event planning.
Worley began his career working with “Entertainment Tonight,” [[MTV]], numerous award shows, and high-profile personalities. Worley was soon donned the “event guru” and budget specialist, known to turn any ordinary event into an extraordinary event.<ref>Azzopardi, Chris. [http://www.pridesource.com/gallery.html?article=52980 "Wedding Do's... and Don'ts"], ''[[PrideSource]]'', April 26, 2012. Retrieved August 2, 2012.</ref><ref>[http://planmywedding.latimesmagazine.com/2011/05/brian-worleys-top-ten-tips-for-the-week-before-the-wedding-.html "401 Days Engaged & Counting: Brian Worley]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', May 4, 2011. Retrieved August 15, 2012.</ref>
Worley’s background in event production and design has led him to creating events such as the recent polo match featuring [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William]] and [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Kate Middleton]] during their visit in the United States on July 8.<ref name="huffingtonpost" /><ref>Shira, Dahvi. [http://www.people.com/people/package/article/0,,20395222_20504469,00.html "Rub Elbows with William and Kate – for $4,000"], ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'', June 22, 2011. Retrieved August 2, 2012.</ref><ref>Netburn, Deborah. [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/alltherage/2011/06/how-to-dress-like-a-princess-on-the-polo-field.html "Meeting Prince William and Catherine on the polo field"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', June 17, 2011. Retrieved August 2, 2012.</ref>
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Hotel del Coronado Wedding.jpg|thumb|right|Brian Worley's Hotel del Coronado Wedding event]] -->
Other events Brian has worked on include: * "My Little Pony: The Royal Wedding" * premiere party for [[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX’s]] new show [[Alcatraz (TV series)|“Alcatraz"]] * "Operation Shower" (a charity that provides baby showers for army wives) * Lounge and gifting suite for the [[Sundance Film Festival]] * CW’s “[[Shedding for the Wedding]],” <ref>{{cite journal|last=Smits|first=Jill|title=Going the Distance|journal=[[USA Today]]|date= March 2011|pages=1–8}}</ref> * [[E!|E!’s]] [[Party Monsters Cabo]] <ref>{{cite web|title=Meet the Cast|url=http://www.eonline.com/on/shows/partymonsterscabo/castbios/index.jsp|publisher=E! Online|date=July 18, 2012}}</ref> * “Oscar Pre-Show,” * [[WE tv|WE TV’s]] “[[Platinum Weddings]],” <ref>[http://www.wetv.com/shows/platinum-weddings "WE tv Platinum Weddings"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120821144447/http://www.wetv.com/shows/platinum-weddings# |date=August 21, 2012 }}, [[WE tv]].</ref> * The Style Channel’s “Big Party Plan Off,” * [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime’s]], [[Get Married (TV series)|“Get Married,”]] * [[TLC (TV channel)|TLC’s]] “Battle of the Wedding Designer,” * [[Black Entertainment Television|BET’s]] [[The Family Crews]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hamm|first=Lisa|author2=Ashley Foley|title=Brian Worley's Pizza Party|journal=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=November 16, 2011|pages=58–60}}</ref> * [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] After Party * Costume Designers Guild Awards * [[Days of Our Lives]] Anniversary Party * Boys and Girls Club Annual Gala * [[Food Network|Food Network's]] "Wedding Impossible"
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Brian Worley wedding event in Ojai, California.png|thumb|right|Brian Worley's wedding event in Ojai, California]] -->
Brian has been featured on the following shows and publications: * CW's [[XETV-TV|San Diego 6 News]] * [[KSWB-TV|Fox 5 San Diego]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Girls Nights: Party Planning Guide|url=http://www.fox5sandiego.com/videogallery/68604880/News/Girls-Night-Party-Planning-Guide#gl-1|accessdate=July 18, 2012|newspaper=Fox 5 San Diego}}</ref> * [[KTLA]] * Vegas Ink * The Doctors * Trailer Codes * [[People (magazine)|People]] Magazine * [[USA Today]] * [[Los Angeles Times]]
==Personal interests== Worley is known for being a green and eco-friendly advocate by implementing the philosophy to “reduce, reuse, and, recycle” through organic and pesticide-free food, bio-diesel generators, rented furniture, recycled fabric, drapes, and linens, and low watt/LED lighting.<ref name="huffingtonpost" /> In 2011, Worley applied this idea through events like the Emmy Awards with 50% recycled material used on the red carpet and conserved 20% of the energy used in lighting.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/09/18/2011-emmy-awards-going-green_n_967697.html "2011 Emmy Award Aims To Go Green"], ''[[Huffington Post]]'', September 18, 2011. Retrieved August 2, 2012.</ref>
Brian Worley currently runs an ongoing blog sharing eco-friendly tips, do it yourself ideas, wedding and event planning guides, and links to his work.<ref>[http://brianworley.wordpress.com/ "Brian Worley: A Guide to Creating Extraordinary Experiences"]. Retrieved August 23, 2012.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

This is a chronicle of important events that took place under the [[Shunzhi Emperor]] of the [[Qing Dynasty]] (1636–1912) in what is now [[China]]. It spans from the death of his predecessor [[Hong Taiji]] (r. 1626–1643) in September 1643, to the emperor's own death on 5 February 1661, seven days into the eighteenth year of the Shunzhi [[Chinese era name|reign period]]. These dates do not correspond perfectly with the Shunzhi era itself, which started on 8 February 1644—on [[Chinese New Year|New Year's Day]] of the [[lunisolar calendar|lunisolar year]] following the emperor's accession—and ended on 17 February 1662 (the last day of the 18th year of Shunzhi), more than one [[solar year]] after the emperor's death. The posthumous events related to the Shunzhi Emperor's burial and posthumous cult are also included.
==Dorgon regency== <!--please do not add anything to this timeline without citing a reliable source (see [[WP:RS]] and [[WP:V]])--thanks-->
===1643=== *'''September 21''': [[Hong Taiji]] dies after a successful seventeen-year reign during which the [[Qing]] became a major power in northeast Asia.<ref>{{harvnb|Oxnam|1975}} (p. 38), {{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}} (p. 297), and {{harvnb|Gong|2010}} (p. 51) all place Hong Taiji's death on September 21 (Chongde 崇德 8.8.9). {{harvnb|Dennerline|2002}} (p. 74) gives the date as September 9.</ref> His death threatens to split the Manchus just as they are preparing to attack the Ming.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|p=74}}.</ref> *'''September 26''': a [[Deliberative Council]] of princes and high officials is convened and decides that five-year-old Fulin, [[Hong Taiji]]'s ninth son, will succeed his father, but that Hong Taiji's half-brother [[Dorgon]] and [[Jirgalang]] will be his co-regents. This deal is a compromise between those who wanted to keep the throne in Hung Taiji's descent (the main candidate was Hong Taiji's eldest son [[Hooge (prince)|Hooge]]) and those who supported Dorgon. *'''October 8''': at the age of six ''sui'', [[Fulin]] officially becomes [[Emperor of China|Emperor]] of the Qing dynasty.<ref>{{harvnb|Fang|1943|p=255}}.</ref>
===1644=== *'''February 8''': in [[Xi'an]], [[Li Zicheng]] founds the "[[Shun Dynasty|Great Shun]]" dynasty and proclaims himself King. *'''February 17''': [[Jirgalang]] willingly yields control of all official matters to his co-regent [[Dorgon]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=299}}.</ref> *'''March 5''': Dorgon sends an amicable letter to Li Zicheng proposing that they "devise a plan in common to unite their forces" against the Ming.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|pages=304}}.</ref> *'''March 17''': the Shun army occupies [[Taiyuan]] in [[Shanxi]]. *'''April 5''': Seeing the progress of rebel armies in north China, the Chongzhen Emperor issues a call for the immediate help of any military commandant in the empire.<ref>{{harvnb|Struve|1988|p=641}}.</ref> *'''April 24''': Li Zicheng enters [[Beijing]], the capital of the [[Ming dynasty|Ming empire]]. *'''April 25''': the [[Chongzhen Emperor]] commits suicide on a hill behind the [[Forbidden City]]. *'''April 26''': [[Wu Sangui]], a powerful Ming general, moves his army through [[Shanhai Pass]] (at the eastern end of the [[Great Wall]]) and marches toward Beijing in response to the emperor's distress call. When he hears that the capital has fallen, Wu returns to fortify Shanhai Pass.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=290}}.</ref> Wu's departure from the fortified city of [[Xingcheng|Ningyuan]], where [[Battle of Ningyuan|Ming armies had defeated]] Qing founder [[Nurhaci]] in 1626, leaves all territory outside the Great Wall under Qing control. *'''April 29''': the victorious Li Zicheng holds an audience with several thousand Ming officials outside the Donghua Gate of the Forbidden City. Assisted by his main [[Grand Secretary]] [[Niu Jinxing]] (牛金星), Li selected 92 officials to serve in the Shun government. The remaining literati are given over to Shun generals for punishment.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|pages=277–79}}.</ref> *'''May 5''': Wu Sangui routs an army led by Tang Tong, which Li Zicheng had despatched to attack Shanhai Pass.<ref name="Wakeman 296">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=296}}.</ref> *'''May 10''': Tang Tong's defeated army returns toward Shanhai Pass with reinforcements, but is again defeated by Wu Sangui. Wu takes the city of Yongping (永平) on the road to Beijing.<ref name="Wakeman 296"/> *'''May 13''': words reach the Qing capital of Shengjing that Li Zicheng has been brutalizing former Ming officials and the population of Beijing. Grand Secretary Fan Wencheng uses these news to argue for a Qing intervention in China.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=304}}.</ref> Dorgon agrees to mount a military expedition to punish the rebels and occupy the Central Plains of China.<ref name="Wakeman 305">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=305}}.</ref> *'''May 14''': Dorgon leads the Qing "Grand Army" out of Shengjing and starts marching south toward the Great Wall.<ref name="Wakeman 305"/> *'''May 18''': After the defeat of two of his armies a few days earlier, Li Zicheng decides to take Shanhai Pass himself: he leaves Beijing with an army of 60,000 troops.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=296}}, note 212.</ref> *'''May 20''': two of Wu Sangui's lieutenants arrive at Dorgon's camp at the [[Liao River]] carrying a message from their master asking the Manchus to help Wu defeat Li Zicheng's bandits and restore the Ming dynasty in return for "great profits" (大利).<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=297}} (date of arrival at the Manchus' camp) and 300–1 (content of the letter).</ref> Dorgon sends a letter back to Wu Sangui offering.<ref name="Wakeman 305"/> Later that day the Manchus hear for the first time that the Chongzhen emperor was dead.<ref name="Wakeman 305"/> Still on that day, but as a result of earlier plans, small groups of Qing troops start to cross the Great Wall to distribute written proclamations announcing that the Qing army will not harm the population and will only kill Li Zicheng's bandits.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|pages=306–307}}.</ref> *'''May 25''': By that date, Li Zicheng's army was already camping in the outskirts of Shanhai Pass, near the Sha River a few kilometers west of the Shanhai Pass garrison; Wu Sangui sends his troops to confront him there.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=309}}.</ref> Dorgon receives a letter confirming that Wu Sangui has accepted to work for the Qing: he takes his army on a forced march toward Shanhai Pass.<ref name="Wakeman 310">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=310}}.</ref> *'''May 26''': having covered more than 150 kilometers in 24 hours, Dorgon's troops settle eight kilometers away from the Pass to rest for a few hours. They are awoken at midnight to continue marching.<ref name="Wakeman 310"/> *'''May 27''': [[Battle of Shanhai Pass]]. At dawn Dorgon's main army reaches the gates of Shanhaiguan, where Dorgon receives Wu Sangui's formal surrender.<ref name="Wakeman 310"/> The armies deploy for battle: placed in the vanguard, Wu's troops are ordered to charge the Shun army, but they are unable to break the rebels' line and suffer heavy casualties. By the late afternoon, they are on the verge of defeat when a sandstorm starts blowing on the battlefield.<ref name="Wakeman 311">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=311}}.</ref> Dorgon chooses this moment to intervene: galloping around Wu's right flank, Qing bannermen destroys Li's left wing.<ref name="Wakeman 311"/> The Shun army is defeated and retreats chaotically toward Yongping; thousands are massacred.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=311–12}}.</ref> *'''May 28''': Li Zicheng retreats from Yongping toward Beijing.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=312}}.</ref> Wu Sangui is named Prince Pingxi; his remaining troops shave their heads and join the Qing forces.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=312}}, note 262.</ref> *'''May 31''': Li Zicheng reenters Beijing with his troops, which started to loot the capital.<ref name="Wakeman 313">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=313}}.</ref> *'''June 3''': as a "final gesture of defiance" after his decisive defeat at Shanhai Pass, Li Zicheng officially declares himself [[Emperor of China|Emperor]] of the Great Shun at the Wuying dian 武英殿.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=313}} (citation and date); {{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=74}} (Wuying dian).</ref> *'''June 4''': after 42 days in Beijing, Li Zicheng sets the imperial palaces on fire and abandons the capital to flee toward the west.<ref name="Wakeman 313"/> The Beijing population massacres rebels who had not fled; nearly two thousand are killed.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=313–14}}.</ref> *'''June 5''': led by Dorgon, Qing troops are welcomed into the capital; the Beijing population is shocked because it was expecting Wu Sangui to bring back the Ming heir apparent.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|pages=314–15}}.</ref> *'''June 7''': Dorgon issues special proclamations to officials around the capital, assuring them that if the local population accepts to cut their hair and to surrender, the officials will be allowed to stay at their post.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=416}}.</ref> (See June 25.) *'''June 25''': because peasant rebellions quickly erupted around the capital in reaction to the haircutting order of June 7, Dorgon issues an edict saying that people will be allowed to arrange their hair the way they want.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 420–422. {{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=84}} gives the date as June 28.</ref> *'''July 14''': Dorgon declares Beijing (which he calls "Yanjing" 燕京) the new capital of the Qing.<ref>{{harvnb|Naquin|2000|p=289}} (gives the date as Shunzhi 1.6.11).</ref> [[Mukden]] (present-day Shenyang), which had been the Qing capital since 1634, is retained as a secondary capital.<ref>{{harvnb|Rawski|1998|p=19}}.</ref> *'''July 29''': at the request of his superior, German [[Jesuit]] missionary [[Johann Adam Schall von Bell]] petitions the Qing throne, claiming that the Jesuit calendar is more accurate than the other ones available.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=857}}, note 24.</ref> *'''October 19''': the six-year-old Emperor arrives in Beijing through the Zhengyang Gate, where he is welcomed by Dorgon.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=857}}.</ref> *'''October 31''': the Jesuit Johann Adam Schall von Bell is made Director of the Bureau of Astronomy (欽天監) after a test of the Jesuits' prediction for an eclipse on September 1 proved to be more accurate than those of the court's official astronomer.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 857–58, note 24.</ref> *'''November 8''': a formal ritual of imperial enthronement is held for Fulin, during which the merits of Dorgon as regent are compared to those of the [[Duke of Zhou]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 858 and 860.</ref> Dorgon's title is raised from "Prince Regent" to "Uncle Prince Regent" (Shufu shezheng wang 叔父攝政王), in which ''shufu'' (''ecike'' in Manchu) represents a rank higher than that of imperial prince.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 860–61, and p. 861, note 31.</ref> *'''November 11''': Hooge is reinstated to the status of [[Prince Su]]; Dorgon's brother Ajige is named Prince Ying; Jirgalang is demoted from "Prince Regent" to "Assistant Uncle Prince Regent" (Fu zheng shuwang 輔政叔王).<ref name="Wakeman 1985 861">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=861}}.</ref>
===1645=== *'''January 20''': the court orders that land without owners be reclaimed and given to Bannermen (圈地). In fact even land that has owners and occupants is confiscated.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|pp=109–10}}.</ref> (Say more.) *'''June 16''': it is declared that all official documents will heretofore refer to Dorgon as "Imperial Uncle Prince Regent" (''Huang shufu shezheng wang'' 皇叔父攝政王).<ref name="Wakeman 1985 861"/> Court ceremonies are also reformed to elevate Dorgon's ritual position even higher.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=862}}.</ref> *'''June 17''': the Prince of Fu, who had been reigning as the "Hongguang Emperor" since June of the previous year, is captured near Nanjing by Qing forces led by [[Liu Liangzuo]].<ref>{{harvnb|Struve|1988|p=666}}.</ref> *'''July 8''': all people who submit to the Qing dynasty are ordered to shave their forehead and tie their hair into a queue.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=128}}.</ref> This "haircutting command" provokes widespread resistance among the Chinese population. *'''July 29''': [[Zhu Yujian]], the Prince of Tang, is named Regent (or "Protector of the State" 監國).<ref name="Struve 1988 665">{{harvnb|Struve|1988|p=665}}.</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=131}}.</ref> *'''August 18''': [[Zhu Yujian]], the Prince of Tang, is proclaimed [[Emperor of China|emperor]] less than a month after arriving in Fuzhou.<ref name="Struve 1988 665"/><ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=140}}.</ref> He will reign under the title of Longwu 隆武. *'''August 24''': fall of [[Jiading District|Jiading]] to the forces of [[Li Chengdong]], a former Ming general who was now serving the Qing; he orders a massacre of the entire population.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 658–59.</ref> *'''September 22''': Li Chengdong takes Songjiang.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=672}}.</ref> *'''October 9''': the city of [[Jiangyin]] falls to Qing armies led by [[Liu Liangzuo]] after a siege of 83 days. The entire population (about 100,000 victims) is massacred over the next two days.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1975|page=83}}.</ref>
===1646=== *'''September 29 and 30''': hearing that Qing troops were approaching, the court of the [[Zhu Yujian, Prince of Tang|Longwu Emperor]] leaves Yanping in western Fujian and tries to flee toward Ganzhou in Jiangxi.<ref name="Struve 676">{{harvnb|Struve|1988|p=676}}.</ref> *'''October 6''': a Qing contingent catches up with the fleeing Longwu Emperor and executes him summarily.<ref name="Struve 676"/> *'''October 17''' or '''27''': the Qing army captures Fuzhou unopposed.<ref>{{harvnb|Struve|1988}} (p. 676) gives October 17; {{harvnb|Gong|2010}} (p. 171) has October 27 (Shunzhi 3.9.19).</ref> *'''November 19''': the Qing forbids officials to memorialize about five controversial issues: haircutting (剃髮), costume (衣冠), the seizure of lands (圈地), (投充), and runaway slaves (逃人).<ref name="Gong 2010 173">{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=173}}.</ref> *'''November 20''': [[Zhu Youlang]], the Ming Prince of Gui, is named protector of the state (監國) in [[Zhaoqing]] (Guangdong); it is decided that he will reign under the title Yongli 永曆.<ref name="Gong 2010 173"/> *'''December 21''': [[Zheng Zhilong]], who had defended the [[Longwu]] court, surrenders to the Qing in Fuzhou. He is taken north as a prisoner.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=176}}.</ref>
===1647=== *'''February 1''': Bandit leader [[Zhang Xianzhong]] is killed in battle by Qing troops led by [[Hooge (prince)|Hooge]], the son of Hong Taiji who had failed to succeed his father on the imperial throne in 1643.<ref>{{harvnb|Dai|2009}}, pp. 17–18.</ref> *'''August 2''': Dorgon's brother Dodo is named [[Dodo, Prince Yu|Prince Yu]].<ref name="Gong 2010 192">{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=192}}.</ref> *'''September 7''': The Qing court forbids Portuguese merchants based in [[Macao]] from entering the provinces to trade.<ref name="Gong 2010 192"/> *'''September 28 / October 27''' (SZ4.9): the court receives an embassy sent by the Ryukyu king to congratulate the Shunzhi Emperor on his accession.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=194}}.</ref>
===1648=== *'''February 25''': Haoge (Prince Su) returns to the capital after his victorious but costly Sichuan campaign (see Feb. 1, 1647).<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=198}}.</ref> *'''March 29''': Dorgon demotes [[Jirgalang]] from Prince Zheng to Prince of the second rank (郡王).<ref name="Gong 2010 199">{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=199}}.</ref> He was given back his rank on '''May 25'''.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=202}}.</ref> *'''April 5''': [[Names of Vietnam|Annam]] sends a tributary embassy to the [[Southern Ming]].<ref name="Gong 2010 199"/> *'''March 24 / April 22''' (SZ5.3): Milayin and Ding Guodong rise against the Qing in Gansu.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=200}}.</ref>
===1649=== *'''April 29''': [[Dodo, Prince Yu|prince Dodo]] (Dorgon's brother from the same mother) dies of [[smallpox]] in Beijing.<ref name="Dennerline 99">{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=99}}.</ref> Dorgon's other [[uterine brother]] Ajige is placed in charge of managing the affairs of the capital.<ref name="Dennerline 99"/> *'''May 27''': [[Empress Xiaoduanwen|Empress Dowager Xiaoduanwen]], [[Hong Taiji]]'s former empress, dies.<ref>''Qingshi gao'' ("[[Draft History of Qing]]"), ch. 214 ("Biographies of consorts" 后妃傳), p. 8901, where the exact date of death is recorded as the ''yisi'' 乙巳 day of the 4th month of the 6th year of Shunzhi.</ref> As a result, the Shunzhi emperor's mother [[Empress Dowager Xiaozhuang]] becomes the most powerful woman in the palace.<ref>{{harvnb|Rawski|1998|p=135}}.</ref> *'''October 4''': Qing banner troops take back [[Datong]] (Shanxi) from the hands of rebellious commander Jiang Xiang.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|p=100}}.</ref> *'''December 30''': [[Geng Zhongming]] (耿仲明; 1604–1649) commits suicide in Jiangxi after being accused of protecting subordinates who had helped three hundred runaway slaves to hide from their masters.<ref name="Wakeman 1985 1017">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=1017}}.</ref> His armies, now led by his son [[Geng Jimao]] (耿繼茂), nonetheless continue to fight the [[Southern Ming]].<ref name="Wakeman 1985 1017"/>
===1650=== *'''November 24''': After a long siege, Qing armies led by [[Shang Kexi]] capture [[Guangzhou|Canton]] and massacre its population.<ref name="Dennerline 101">{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=101}}.</ref> Firmly entrenched in the south, Shang later became one of the [[Three Feudatories]]. *'''November 26''': [[Kong Youde]] 孔有德 (1602–1652) captures [[Guilin]] ([[Guangxi]]) for the Qing.<ref name="Dennerline 101"/> *'''December 31''': Dorgon dies at the age of 38 during a hunting expedition.<ref name="Dennerline 101"/> His death created an immediate backlash against his political allies at court.
==Transition and personal rule== <!--please do not add anything to this timeline without citing a reliable source (see [[WP:CITE]] and [[WP:V]])--thanks-->
===1651=== *'''January 26''': Dorgon's brother [[Ajige]] is imprisoned for allegedly plotting a coup after the death of Dorgon.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002}}, pp. 101–102.</ref> He was forced to commit suicide later that year.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=104}}.</ref> *'''April 7''': the Shunzhi Emperor issues an edict declaring his intention to root out corruption among officials.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=106}}.</ref> The anticorruption campaign that followed first targeted officials who had been close to Dorgon, but it soon led to a revival of factional politics among literati officials, a problem that plagued the young emperor until his death in 1661.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002}}, pp. 106–107.</ref> *'''September''': the emperor marries a niece of his mother the Empress Dowager.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=929}}.</ref> *'''October 31''': the monumental "Gate of Receiving Heaven" (Chengtian men 承天門) facing south from the imperial city is renamed "Gate of Heavenly Peace" ([[Tiananmen]] 天安門).<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=928}}.</ref> *'''December 13''': Consort Ba 巴 gives birth to Niuniu 牛鈕, the Shunzhi emperor's first son.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 127, Shunzhi 8.11.乙亥 (1st). The mother is named in ''Qingshi gao'', ch. 219, p. 9052.</ref>
===1652=== *'''March 9''': death of the emperor's first son Niuniu less than three months after his birth.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 128, Shunzhi 9.1.壬寅 (30th).</ref> *'''Spring''': in an edict to the [[Inner Three Courts]], the Shunzhi Emperor orders that all memorials concerning state matters should now be sent to him rather than to Jirgalang's office.<ref name="Lui 46">{{harvnb|Lui|1989|p=46}}.</ref> This marks the time when the monarch takes full charge of the government.<ref name="Lui 46"/> *'''August 7''': Southern Ming loyalist [[Li Dingguo]], an ancient lieutenant of bandit king [[Zhang Xianzhong]], retakes the key southwestern city of [[Guilin]] from the Qing; the Qing commander-in-chief Kong Youde commits suicide.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 972 (Kong commits suicide) and 973, note 194 (taking of Guilin by Li).</ref> Within a month, most of the [[Guangxi]] military commanders who had served the Qing reverted to the Ming side.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=973}}, note 194.</ref>
===1653=== *'''January 14''': the [[Fifth Dalai Lama]] arrives in Beijing to meet with the Shunzhi Emperor.<ref>{{harvnb|Li|2003|p=476}}; {{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=258}} (the former cites the entry from the Qing ''Veritable Records'' indicating the date of the Dalai Lama's arrival).</ref> He leaves about two months later.<ref>{{harvnb|Li|2003|p=476}}.</ref> *'''April 25''': the emperor recalls [[Feng Quan]] 馮銓 to serve in the government again.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=954}}.</ref> That very evening he was summoned to meet with the emperor, [[Hong Chengchou]], and [[Chen Mingxia]] 陳名夏<ref>{{cite journal |last=Godley |first=Michael R. |last2= |first2= |date= |title=The End of the Queue: Hair as Symbol in Chinese History |url=http://www.chinaheritagequarterly.org/features.php?searchterm=027_queue.inc&issue=027 |journal=China Heritage Quarterly |publisher=The Australian National University |volume= |issue= |pages= |doi= |access-date=23 August 2016}}</ref> to discuss the qualifications of [[Hanlin Academy]] compilers, who had been mostly appointed by Chen Mingxia, a southerner.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=956}}.</ref> Even though Shunzhi was trying to counteract the influence of southern Chinese officials who advocated a return to Ming government practices, by recalling a pro-Manchu collaborator like Feng Quan, he actually intensified the tensions between northern and southern Chinese literati.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=958}}.</ref> *'''July 23''': to counteract the power of the [[Imperial Household Department]], Shunzhi establishes the Thirteen Offices (内十三衙门), which are controlled by eunuchs.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=931}}. The exact date can be found in {{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=266}}.</ref> These bureaus allowed eunuch power to grow;<ref>{{harvnb|Fang|1943|p=257}}.</ref> they were eliminated by Oboi and the other regents at the beginning of the Kangxi reign. *'''September 8''': Consort Ningyi 寧懿 of the [[Donggo]] clan gives birth to [[Fuquan (prince)|Fuquan]], the emperor's second son.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 135, Shunzhi 10.7.庚戌 (17th).</ref> He died in 1703.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 8, p. 263, Kangxi 42.6.壬寅 (28th), or August 10, 1703.</ref> *'''December 15''': The court forbids actors (優人) from not shaving their hair on the pretext that they have to play female roles.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=267}}.</ref>
===1654=== *'''March 8''': [[Shang Kexi]] is appointed to govern 鎮 [[Guangdong]], whereas [[Geng Jimao]] is ordered to garrison [[Guilin]] and to take care of the Green Standard Armies that had been established by [[Kong Youde]].<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=269}}.</ref> *'''April 27''': on recommendation by the [[Deliberative Council of Princes and Ministers]] led by [[Jirgalang]], [[Chen Mingxia]] (陳名夏), who had been an influential [[Grand Secretary]], is executed by strangling after a ten-day trial for corruption that started when he proposed to restore the hairstyle and court costume of the Ming dynasty.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|pages=985–86}}.</ref> *'''May 4''': [[Xiao Hui Zhang|Empress Xiaohui]] gives birth to the emperor third son [[Xuanye]] 玄燁 ([[Manchu language|Manchu]]: {{MongolUnicode|ᡥᡳᠣᠸᠠᠨ ᠶᡝᡳ}} Hiowan Yei), who later became the [[Kangxi Emperor]].
===1655=== *'''March 14''': Jirgalang asks the Emperor to establish an Imperial Diarist 起居注官 to keep a diary of the emperor's movements.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=270}}.</ref>
===1656=== *'''August 6''': The Qing forbids sea trade in the southeastern provinces. Private merchant ships are forbidden from trading and other ships from accosting.<ref name="Gong 2010 288">{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=288}}.</ref> The purpose of this policy was to eliminate those among sea merchants who supported the Southern Ming power of [[Zheng Chenggong]].<ref name="Gong 2010 288"/>
===1657=== *'''November 5''': [[Empress Xiao Xian|Imperial Noble Consort Donggo]], the emperor's favorite consort, gives birth to the emperor's fourth son, who died before he was given a name (see February 25, 1658). *'''November 30''': the Shuntian examination cheating scandal erupts.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=295}}.</ref> *'''December 8''': the emperor's fifth son, [[Changning (prince)|Changning]], is born to Consort Chen 陳.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 150, Shunzhi 14.11.壬寅 (4th). The mother is named in ''Qingshigao'', ch. 219, p. 9052.</ref> He became Prince Gong (恭親王) in 1671 and died in 1703.<ref>Date of his becoming prince: ''Qingshi gao'', ch. 6, p. 180, Kangxi 10.1.癸酉 (21st), i.e., 1 March 1671. Date of death: ''Qingshi gao'', ch. 8, p. 263, Kangxi 42.6.辛巳 (7th), i.e., 20 July 1703.</ref>
===1658=== *'''February 25''': death of the emperor's fourth son a little more than 100 days after his birth. He was posthumously granted the title of Prince Rong (榮親王).<ref>{{Harvnb|Li|2003|pp=594–95}}.</ref> *'''August 13''': the emperor changes the old Manchu Inner Three Courts into a "Palace Secretariat" (''diange'' 殿閣) and reinstitutes the old [[Hanlin Academy]], both based on old Ming institutions.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=1007}}.</ref> Though these institutions were abrogated during the [[Oboi regency]] (1661–1669), the [[Kangxi Emperor]] reinstated them in 1670 (the former as the "Grand Secretariat," or ''neige'' 內閣) and they lasted until the end of the Qing in 1911.
===1659=== *'''January 25''': Qing forces led by prince Dodo's second son Doni enter the capital of Yunnan, sending the [[Yongli Emperor]] into flight to Burma under the protection of [[Li Dingguo]].<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=117}}. {{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=1034}} gives the date as January 23.</ref> *'''March 7''': the core of the Southern Ming army is defeated at [[Dali City|Dali]], forcing the [[Yongli Emperor]], the last monarch of the southern Ming, to flee toward [[Burma]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=1034}}.</ref>
===1660=== *'''January 3''': birth of the emperor's sixth son Qishou 奇授 (Manchu: Kišeo) to Consort Tang 唐.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 156, Shunzhi 16.11.戊寅 (21st). The mother is identified in ''Qingshi gao'', ch. 219, p. 9052.</ref> He died at an unspecified date at the age of seven [[East Asian age reckoning|''sui'']].<ref name="Qingshi gao, ch. 214, p. 8910">''Qingshi gao'', ch. 214, p. 8910.</ref> *'''March 6''': to counter factional politics, the Shunzhi emperor issues an edict banning clubs or societies whose purpose was to influence government affairs or public opinion.<ref>{{harvnb|Struve|1982|p=258}}.</ref> *'''May 30''': Consort Niu gives birth to the emperor's seventh son, Longxi 隆禧 (Manchu: Lunghi).<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, pp. 158–59, Shunzhi 17.4.丙午 (22nd).</ref> He died in 1679.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 6, p. 200, Kangxi 18.7.丁未 (15th), or August 20, 1679.</ref> *'''September 23''': death of the emperor's favorite concubine, "Imperial Consort of the Second Rank" Donggo.<ref>{{harvnb|Standaert|2008|p=72}}.</ref> Jesuit missionary [[Adam Schall]], who had been close to the emperor in 1656 and 1657 and who attended the concubine's expensive funerals, later claimed that "Through her death she made [the emperor] fall into a madness more repulsive than the one of [[Solomon|Salomon]], because he openly displayed himself as a disciple of [[Sangha (Buddhism)|the Bonzes]], shaving his head, and living and dressing himself like them."<ref>{{harvnb|Standaert|2008}} pp. 72 (in the words of Schall, "a very great Funeral" with many "wasteful ceremonies") and 74 (citation).</ref>
===1661=== *'''January 23''': birth of the emperor's eighth son, Yonggan, to Consort Muktu 穆克圖.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 161, Shunzhi 17.12.甲辰 (23rd). The mother is mentioned in ''Qingshi gao'', ch. 219, p. 9052.</ref> He died at an unspecified date at the age of eight [[East Asian age reckoning|''sui'']].<ref name="Qingshi gao, ch. 214, p. 8910"/> *'''February 5''': the Shunzhi emperor dies of [[smallpox]].<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=118}}.</ref>
==After death== <!--please do not add anything to this timeline without citing a reliable source (see [[WP:RS]] and [[WP:V]])--thanks-->
===1661=== *'''March 2''': in a lavish procession, the emperor's body is transported to Jingshan—north of the Forbidden City—where it stayed for about two years until the emperor was finally buried.<ref>{{harvnb|Standaert|2008|pp=74–75}}.</ref> On '''March 3''' a large number of precious goods are burned as offerings, after which the [[Kangxi Emperor|new emperor]] takes off his mourning dress.<ref>{{harvnb|Standaert|2008|pp=73–74}}.</ref> *'''April 22''': the dead emperor is given a [[temple name]] (Shizu 世祖)—by which he would be worshipped at the [[Imperial Ancestral Temple]]—and an honorific [[posthumous name]] (體天隆運定統建極英睿欽文顯武大德弘功至仁純孝章皇帝 ''Titian longyun dingtong jianji yingrui qinwen xianwu dade honggong zhiren chunxiao zhang huangdi'').<ref>''Qingshi gao'' ["[[Draft History of Qing]]"], ch. 5, p. 163: Shunzhi 18.3.癸酉 (24th day of that month).</ref>
===1662=== *'''January 13''': the ancestral tablets of the Shunzhi emperor are placed at the [[Imperial Ancestral Temple]], where he will be worshipped under the [[temple name]] Shizu.<ref>''Qingshi gao'' ["[[Draft History of Qing]]"], chapter 6, p. 167. Date: Shunzhi 18.11.己亥 (24th day of that month).</ref>
===1663=== *'''July 5 / August 2''' (KX2.6): the emperor's body is buried at the Xiaoling.<ref>''Qingshi gao'' ["[[Draft History of Qing]]"], chapter 6, p. 169.</ref>

'''Diminished value''', Diminution in Value, or commonly referred to as "DV" are the terms generally used to describe the economic loss in a property's value as a result of having been damaged. Diminished Value (DV) is often associated with vehicles that have been damaged, however, it is applicable to other property of value including collectibles such as jewelry, artwork, etc. For the purposes herein, reference will involve the loss in value of a damaged automobile where the term is often applied.
Unlike "depreciation", which is an anticipated and predictable loss in value over time, ‘Inherent Diminished Value’ is a loss in value due to a specific, sudden and unexpected negative occurrence. Diminished value of an automobile following an accident may occur in one of three ways (or a combination thereof):
(1) repair-related diminished value;
(2) Immediate diminished value; and
(3) inherent diminished value.
'''Repair-related diminished value''' is the loss of value due to the inability to perfectly repair the vehicle, so it is worth less after repairs than it was before the wreck. '''Immediate Diminished Value''' – The difference in resale value of a vehicle immediately before damage has occurred and immediately after damage has occurred (prior to repair). As courts are rarely the chosen venue for recovery of property damage, the standard of "Immediate Diminished Value" is rarely employed in resolving Property Damage claims. This also refers to a loss of value caused by the insurer's direct involvement in the claim adjustment in which the insurer exerts control over the repairs and repairs are incomplete, insufficiently performed, or otherwise restore the vehicle to less than the standard condition.
'''Inherent Diminished Value''' - Assumes optimal repair quality has been achieved and is defined as the amount by which the resale value of a repaired vehicle has been reduced simply because the subject vehicle now has a significant damage history. This is the most widely recognized and accepted form of Diminished Value. It is also the basis upon which any supplemental form of Diminished Value would be added. A common "Supplemental" form of Diminished Value is "Repair Related Diminished Value".
Usually, a frame or structurally damaged vehicle cannot be re-sold as a "[[certified pre-owned]] vehicle."
The true measure of a damaged vehicle's inherent loss in value can be measured as the difference in the value of the vehicle before the loss to that after the loss, prior to or after repair. The standard rule as to establishing a value on late model vehicles would be: 20-25% behind book (Black Book, KBB, NADA) and utilize actual sales results, and not on advertised prices.
While some may claim Diminished Value (DV) is subjective and based upon perception or speculation, the old adage "perception becomes reality' applies and as such Diminution in Value is real simply because, for the most part, no reasonable and prudent person is willing to pay the same price for a vehicle with a history of damage as they would for one never having been damaged. Retailers often offer discounts for scratches and dents on appliances, electronics and dented canned goods; it is, therefore, reasonable that the value of a damaged motor vehicle will suffer a lessening in value.
Additional factors may be taken into consideration in evaluating the loss in value of a damaged and repaired vehicle and may include, but not be limited to: the vehicle itself (i.e. rare collectible, originality, market desirability etc.), the vehicle’s pre-loss condition, severity of the sustained damages (i.e. frame damage, flood, fire etc.), the subject vehicle’s history (i.e. one owner, prior damage/repair, death of occupants etc.), quality and thoroughness of the performed repairs, (i.e. quality of parts, materials, workmanship, etc.) and additional value considerations including, but not limited to values associated with pre-owned certification programs.etc.
Auto insurance companies may not readily recognize or offer to pay for diminished value. Each state may have differing opinions of DV. Example; The state of Georgia allows the insured party (the first-party Policyholder) to make a claim for their remaining economic loss for DV from their own insurance company while the neighboring state of Florida does not. Most states, however, allow the victim of another's negligence (third-party) to make a DV claim from the at-fault party.
The length of time to collect Diminished Value will vary depending upon each state's statute of limitations for first party (contractual) claims and third-party (restatement of tort) claims.
==Diminished Value Appraisal== {{original research|section|date=January 2013}} A diminished value [[wikt:appraisal|appraisal]] evaluates the difference in value of a [[motor vehicle]] after a collision repair. Reports are usually compiled by an Auto Appraisal Expert experienced in the field of DV and who may provide expert testimony for Appraisals, Arbitration, Mediation or Litigation in a court of law. This Assessment report is used when filing or disputing a diminished value claim against another party and/or an [[insurance]] company. The report measures a damaged vehicle’s inherent loss in value. The diminished value can be measured as the difference in the value of the vehicle before the loss to that after the loss, prior to or after repair. In most cases even if the repair was done expertly, the value of the automobile will still be considerably less after a loss. When consumers find that a vehicle has been in an accident, most consumers will never pay the same price for a repaired vehicle as compared to one with no loss history.
Some reports include an assessment of the damage done to a motor vehicle, the quality of the performed repair, the market value of the vehicle before and after the accident.{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}} <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.diminishedvalue.law/info-center/how-to-prove-diminished-value-of-a-vehicle/|title=Coffey Trial Law - Diminished Value|website=www.diminishedvalue.law|language=en|access-date=2017-08-16}}</ref>There are no set rules for measuring diminished value, and since every vehicle loses value differently, a one size fits all formula would be fundamentally inaccurate.
==Regional== Recognition of concept of diminished value varies from country to country {{citation needed|date=January 2013}}
===United States=== Some states' statutes acknowledge diminished value and provide the ability for consumers to collect first party claims of DV from their own insurance companies under their own policies. Most states allow the consumer to collect third party claims from the at-fault driver's insurance company. Some states recognize liability for third party claims but not first party claims.<ref>http://www.mwl-law.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/diminution-of-value-in-all-50-states.pdf</ref>
===Georgia=== In Georgia, vehicle owners can collect DV against their own policy.
=== Florida === Diminished value is part of the Florida Standard Civil Jury Instructions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Florida Standard Jury Instructions - Civil|url=http://www.floridasupremecourt.org/civ_jury_instructions/instructions.shtml#500|publisher=State of Florida|language=en-us}}</ref> Diminished value [[case law]] in Florida is based primarily on two cases.
* Siegle vs. Progressive Consumer's Insurance Company, '''819 So.2d 732''' (Florida 2002). The ability to receive diminished value [[financial compensation]] from an at-fault driver for their negligence was decided by the [[Florida Supreme Court]] in the Siegle vs. Progressive Consumer's Insurance Company case. After Siegle insurance companies are able to exclude responsibility for the payment of diminished value to the vehicle that they insure through the language in the policy. * McHale vs. Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Co. '''409 So.2d 238''' (1982) The [[Florida Third District Court of Appeal]], upheld that the correct measure of damages is the cost of repair plus any reduction in the value of the vehicle. The Court also directed that proving the reduction in value is the burden of the [[Plaintiff]] bringing the claim.
=== Louisiana === Diminished value is provided in [http://legis.la.gov/legis/Law.aspx?d=408380 Louisiana Revised Statute 9:2800.17]. The vehicle owner must prove by a preponderance of evidence that the fair market value would be less than its value before the vehicle was damaged.
===Washington=== On July 15, 2014, a policyholder in Washington state filed a proposed class action lawsuit in the Superior Court of Pierce County seeking diminished value insurance benefits under their automobile insurance policies. The insurance company filed a notice to remove the lawsuit to federal district court on August 20, 2014. The case is titled ''Johnston v. United Services Automobile Ass'n''.
===Canada=== The ability to recover damages for accelerated depreciation varies from Province to Province.{{citation needed|date=January 2013}}
In [[British Columbia]], law recognizes this loss as a recoverable damage and quantify the claim based on the diminished value at the time the collision occurs.<ref>[http://www.bclaws.ca/EPLibraries/bclaws_new/document/LOC/freeside/--%20c%20--/court%20rules%20act%20rsbc%201996%20c.%2080/05_regulations/19_168_2009%20supreme%20court%20civil%20rules/168_2009_02.xml Rule 11-2 BC Supreme Court]</ref>
The Rules addressing the admissibility of depreciation reports in court vary by jurisdiction.{{citation needed|date=January 2013}} For example, in British Columbia, Canada, [http://www.bclaws.ca/EPLibraries/bclaws_new/document/LOC/freeside/--%20C%20--/Court%20Rules%20Act%20RSBC%201996%20c.%2080/05_Regulations/19_168_2009%20Supreme%20Court%20Civil%20Rules/168_2009_02.xml#part11 the BC Supreme Court requires such reports to comply with Rule 11].
==See also== * [[Impaired asset]] * [[Write-off]] * [[Depreciation]] * [[Certified pre-owned]] * [[Statute of limitations]] * [[Loss of use]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
